intro: Acanthopanax gracilistylus var. major, commonly known as the giant Chinese dogwood, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to China. It is characterized by its compound leaves, which are typically arranged in a whorled pattern along the stems. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers followed by red berries that are edible for birds and mammals. It thrives in temperate climates and is often found in forested areas with well-drained soil. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.

This plant is commonly found in dense forests and secondary growth areas, often growing as a shrub or small tree. It is well adapted to the shaded understory conditions of these forest ecosystems. The species is also occasionally reported in northern Vietnam and northeastern India.
